The occasion also contained an international conference on Slavic literature in France. During the conference there were many discussions on the ways in which the Serbian and Croatian literary traditions could serve as a bridge for the European literary project. The most significant among them was the conference held on 14-15th January 1959, in Paris between Srdja Trifunovic, the literary critic and leader of the Slovene Renaissance, and Jadranka Lajeva (later president-designate of the Council of Europe).

The Slovene Renaissance was a political movement and it took an active part in the formation of a new Slovenia. It was strongly in favour of the "cultural autonomy" of Slovenia, its independence from central authority.

Compared to other team sports, the National Football League preseason is very structured. Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year, two of which are "home" games (in other words, played in their home stadium) and two which are "away" games. The team in each of the four home "away" games plays the other team the next week and the teams play their "home" and "away" opponents the following week. Each team only plays four pre-season games, but there is a long-term schedule for each team in the preseason and postseason. Each team starts the preseason in the same week it goes onto the field for the regular season. For instance, the Philadelphia Eagles begin the first preseason game on Thursday, April 13, and finish the fourth preseason game on Sunday, April 20.

The 2016 NFL preseason schedule was released on November 27, 2016, and it will likely serve as a reminder of what the teams will be facing next year

In this field researchers often concentrate on how particular phenomena relate to matters of ideology, nationality, ethnicity, social class, and/or gender.[citation needed] Cultural studies has a concern with the meaning and practices of everyday life. This field studies the meanings and uses people attribute to various objects and practices. Specifically, culture involves those meanings and practices held independently of reason. original: Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. Light-dark color variation is common in the mammalian taxa. Sometimes, this color variation is determined by age variation, however, in other cases, it is determined by other factors. Selective pressures, such as ecological interactions with other populations or environmental conditions, often lead to the variation in mammalian coloration. These selective pressures favor certain colors in order to increase survival. Camouflage is thought to be a major selection pressure shaping coloration in mammals, although there is also evidence that sexual selection, communication, and physiological processes may influence the evolution of coloration as well. Camouflage is the most predominant mechanism for color variation, as it aids in the concealment of the organisms from predators or from their prey. Coat color can also be for intraspecies communication such as warning members of their species about predators, indicating health for reproductive purposes, communicating between mother and young, and intimidating predators. Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. This variation between populations and species is one of the primary means of differentiation among mammals.

Some mammals have a large number of hairs on one side of the face, such as the mouse. Such a hair appears on the face of one or both sides of the upper lip, under the chin, and is arranged in a ring around the eyes. The hairs are dark in color and are usually small. A few mammals such as the rhesus macaque, an important research model, have very few hair follicles on one side of the face, the eyebrows.

However, for most of recorded history, agriculture and foraging were inter-twined, in a way that still applies today, which is one of the main reasons why there have been significant and mutually beneficial relationships between modern humans and traditional (and sometimes even semi-modern) societies in general. A simple example of this is that of the domestication of plants, the introduction of cattle, and later the establishment of grain-based economies. In fact, early farmers and herders have been seen as the primary ancestors of our modern agricultural communities and in many cases have in fact become some of our most important predecessors in terms of cultural innovation and technological achievement.

Knowledge, for Popper, was objective, both in the sense that it is objectively true (or truthlike), and also in the sense that it is a product of the human mind itself. It can then be contrasted with other kinds of knowledge: "What you know and don't know, what you want to know and what you don't, is a different affair; but whether you know or don't know is part of the same thing." A further distinction between the two domains is of course made by Popper (and not, as some might have it, between scientific knowledge of the present state of affairs and knowledge of the truth of propositions in general).

Strict separation of powers did not operate in The United Kingdom, the political structure of which served in most instances[citation needed] as a model in the rest of the British Empire.[26] There was no concept of 'the Crown'. In the British system of government the prime minister was held directly responsible and answerable to Parliament. There was no executive authority, no 'executive branch'. Ministers did not have the power to 'declare war', and no power to 'order' the British armed forces to execute orders of their ministers.[27]

All executive powers rested with the head of State and his minister.[citation needed]

In this system, powers were vested in the monarch, the government and the government ministers. In all instances, power was vested directly into the hands of the prime minister. They ran into difficulties when attempting to expand into the Netherlands (1515). A royal commission was established to monitor the activities of foreign merchants (1556) and by the end of the century French interests in the Netherlands had shrunk to a minimum (1568), even as French power spread into the lowlands of Europe (1627).

The most important of these changes was the development of the French empire from the 16th to the 19th century, and the end of the Renaissance. However, much of the empire was left undefended when the Germans defeated the French at the Second Battle of Agincourt (1615) and drove the emperor from Europe.

The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea was divided into several smaller and younger landmasses, such as Laurasia, Gondwana and Neoproterozoic Canada. North America is considered a part of Laurasia and is part of the supercontinent Gondwana. original: Despite efforts to revive Hebrew as the national language of the Jewish people, knowledge of the language is not commonly possessed by Jews worldwide and English has emerged as the lingua franca of the Jewish diaspora. Although many Jews once had sufficient knowledge of Hebrew to study the classic literature, and Jewish languages like Yiddish and Ladino were commonly used as recently as the early 20th century, most Jews lack such knowledge today and English has by and large superseded most Jewish vernaculars. completed: Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle . For most , the search for identity begins in the adolescent years . During these years , adolescents are searching within and without for some clue to their “ true selves ” . As young people begin to define themselves and discover their places in their families , friendships , and the wider world , adolescent identity development begins . Identity development occurs through the processes of differentiation and integration . Differentiation refers to the separation from parents and the development of an identity away from the family of origin . Integr ation , on the other hand , refers to an emergent sense of connected ness with one ’ s peers and the larger society . At this stage , the young person is seeking to figure out the true meaning of life . During this stage , parents should encourage the child to explore new ways of living as well as to find out as much as possible about other cultures .

original: Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid instead of urea or ammonia through the ureters into the intestine. Birds do not have a urinary bladder or external urethral opening and (with exception of the ostrich) uric acid is excreted along with feces as a semisolid waste. However, birds such as hummingbirds can be facultatively ammonotelic, excreting most of the nitrogenous wastes as ammonia. They also excrete creatine, rather than creatinine like mammals. This material, as well as the output of the intestines, emerges from the bird's cloaca. The cloaca is a multi-purpose opening: waste is expelled through it, most birds mate by joining cloaca, and females lay eggs from it. In addition, many species of birds regurgitate pellets. Many vertebrates, such as salamanders, lagomorphs - a group of extinct mammals - have no uric acids. Instead their high uric acid content is taken up in a form similar to urea, used to produce urea which then converts to urochromes and urea-glucuronide. So a carnivore (or other obligate carnivore, since that usually relies on blood to survive) will always have a high concentration of urea-based proteins even if it has no uric acid.


In birds, the most common uric acid is chystrale, which is found in about 80 and 75 percent of the birds tested. The other uric acid is uric acid, which is made by birds at an even higher concentration.

original: When Nintendo released the NES in the US, the design styling was deliberately different from that of other game consoles. Nintendo wanted to distinguish its product from those of competitors and to avoid the generally poor reputation that game consoles had acquired following the video game crash of 1983. One result of this philosophy was to disguise the cartridge slot design as a front-loading zero insertion force (ZIF) cartridge socket, designed to resemble the front-loading mechanism of a VCR. The newly designed connector worked quite well when both the connector and the cartridges were clean and the pins on the connector were new. Unfortunately, the ZIF connector was not truly zero insertion force. When a user inserted the cartridge into the NES, the force of pressing the cartridge down and into place bent the contact pins slightly, as well as pressing the cartridge’s ROM board back into the cartridge itself. Sound could be stored in either analog or digital format and in a variety of surround sound formats; NTSC discs could carry two analog audio tracks, plus or minus one, while PAL-specification discs could carry three analog audio tracks, plus or minus two.

Sound was stored in the sound device. Audio signals were transmitted directly to the sound device and then encoded into a standard bit stream, which could then be decoded at the sound device. The signal could be stored on a magnetic disk or recorded on to a phonograph disc.

Because of the way these machines stored sound, some sources such as a tape may be better than others. For example, a phonograph may sound better than vinyl on some types of recordings. Jean Macfarlane founded the University of California, Berkeley's Institute of Human Development, formerly called the Institute of Child Welfare, in 1927. The Institute was designed to provide research, education and supervision to improve educational and child-rearing practices. Macfarlane was a pioneer of gender studies and a leading proponent of the feminist movement.

Over the decades, the Institute continued to evolve with Macfarlane's passing in 1976, and the Institute's faculty and affiliates became stronger. The Institute's most recent director, the feminist scholar Donna Haraway, received the 1993 American Psychological Association Award for distinguished service to psychology, as well as the 1993 American Psychological Association Women's Leadership Award.

Through its programs and fellowships, the Institute supports graduate students and undergraduate scholars in human development with opportunities for research, teaching and research training. The Institute also supports the graduate and professional schools, libraries and archives of the University of California, Berkeley.

Many local people used Carnival as a chance to entertain their neighbors and friends with displays of merriment, song, and dance. The most famous Carnival of the Middle Ages was that which was held at Saint-Germain-des-Prés on March 9-12.

The feast fell in late spring as spring gave way naturally to summer, and, with the changing temperatures, became the most important period in France's year. It represented the renewal of life and the beginning of winter. The festivities for the 12th of March included street and tavern markets, food courts, games, and theatrical performances. In the countryside, peasants threw large parties to celebrate.

Many local Carnival customs are claimed to derive from the rituals of these medieval celebrations , or to have been a carryover of pagan festivals [ 6 ] or surv iivals of medieval practices . One of the earliest examples of Carnival celebration was found upon the ruins of the ancient Greek city -state of Cyrene in modern Libya . There are indications on the ruins of ancient buildings that carnival parties were held there in the 5th century BC . Carnival seems to have existed in many other parts of the world , too . It was celebrated in Spain during the reign of Ferdinand the Catholic , and in Portugal during the reign of Afonso V [ 7 ] . original: Adolescence marks a rapid change in one's role within a family. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much influence over family decisions until early adolescence, when they are increasingly viewed by parents as equals. The adolescent faces the task of increasing independence while preserving a caring relationship with his or her parents. When children go through puberty, there is often a significant increase in parent–child conflict and a less cohesive familial bond. Arguments often concern minor issues of control, such as curfew, acceptable clothing, and the adolescent's right to privacy, which adolescents may have previously viewed as issues over which their parents had complete authority. Parent-adolescent disagreement also increases as friends demonstrate a greater impact on one another, new influences on the adolescent that may be in opposition to parents' values. Children enter maturity between the ages of 10 and 15. They develop and increase in physical strength and begin to develop social maturity. original: The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals, the Soviet Union (USSR) and the United States (US), for supremacy in spaceflight capability. It had its origins in the missile-based nuclear arms race between the two nations that occurred following World War II, enabled by captured German rocket technology and personnel. In the bataillon-carré system, the various corps of the Grande Armée would march uniformly together in close supporting distance. If any single corps was attacked, the others could quickly spring into action and arrive to help. Napoleon invaded Prussia with 180,000 troops, rapidly marching on the right bank of the River Saale. original: To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different species have since adapted to meet their dietary requirements in a variety of ways. Some eat other animals – this is a carnivorous diet (and includes insectivorous diets). Other mammals, called herbivores, eat plants. A herbivorous diet includes subtypes such as fruit-eating and grass-eating. An omnivore eats both prey and plants. Carnivorous mammals have a simple digestive tract, because the proteins, lipids, and minerals found in meat require little in the way of specialized digestion. Plants, on the other hand, contain complex carbohydrates, such as cellulose. The digestive tract of an herbivore is therefore host to bacteria that ferment these substances, and make them available for digestion. The bacteria are either housed in the multichambered stomach or in a large cecum. The size of an animal is also a factor in determining diet

This is achieved by Neutral Sections (also known as Phase Breaks), usually provided at feeder stations and midway between them although, typically, only half are in use at any time, the others being provided to allow a feeder station to be shut down and power provided from adjacent feeder stations. Neutral Sections usually consist of an earthed section of wire which is separated from the live wires on either side by insulating material, typically ceramic beads, designed so that the pantograph will smoothly run from one section to the other. The earthed section prevents an arc being drawn from one live section to the other, as the voltage difference may be higher than the normal system voltage if the live sections are on different phases and the protective circuit breakers may not be able to safely interrupt the considerable current that would flow. Most fatty acids are non-essential, meaning the body can produce them as needed, generally from other fatty acids and always by expending energy to do so.

The best sources of fatty acids are animal fat and high-fat plant foods like coconut oil and flax seeds.

Fatty acids have special structures, known as fatty acid chains, in their chemical structures that can be attached to molecules of fat or other substances, such as sugars, protein, and vitamins. Thus, the essential fatty acid is actually a chain of non-essential fatty acids, made up of chains of alternating fatty acid chains.

Essential fatty acids are considered to be nutrients essential to a healthy body and mind, whereas non-essential fatty acids can be included in any of the normal food groups in a diet. Following the Sergeant Isaac Woodard incident, President Harry S. Truman, himself a combat veteran of World War I, issued Executive Order 9808 establishing the Armed Forces Radio Broadcast Service in June 1942.

Truman's order required all military members to establish and maintain radio stations, to receive regular transmissions from Army units operating in various theaters of operation, to transmit such transmissions, and, of course, to transmit them, not only as a military broadcast but also for their general dissemination through civilian stations and wire services. By issuing his orders, Truman committed the U.S. Army to the radio project.

Despite the war efforts, the radio broadcast service proved to be less efficient than the wire service. This was due to a number of factors, including Army officials' insistence that Army units be authorized to transmit over the radio, without having to first obtain approval from the State Governors. The service also faced logistical difficulties--radio transmission equipment was of poor quality and many stations experienced technical difficulties.

original: Communication within peer groups allows adolescents to explore their feelings and identity as well as develop and evaluate their social skills. Peer groups offer members the opportunity to develop social skills such as empathy, sharing, and leadership. Adolescents choose peer groups based on characteristics similarly found in themselves. By utilizing these relationships, adolescents become more accepting of who they are becoming. Group norms and values are incorporated into an adolescent’s own self-concept. Through developing new communication skills and reflecting upon those of their peers, as well as self-opinions and values, an adolescent can share and express emotions and other concerns without fear of rejection or judgment. Peer groups can have positive influences on an individual, such as on academic motivation and performance. However, while peers may facilitate social development for one another they may also hinder it. Peers can have negative influences, such as encouraging experimentation with drugs, drinking, vandalism, and stealing through peer pressure. Susceptibility to peer pressure increases during early adolescence, peaks around age 14, and declines thereafter. Further evidence of peers hindering social development has been found in Spanish

Despite the loss of the Great Charter following a series of rebellions, Penn continued to seek new tracts of land. With the help of Pennsylvania legislators, like the Honorable Nathaniel Bradford, he acquired two tracts near Plymouth and another near Philadelphia.

The Treaty of London on April 29, 1691 placed responsibility for paying the debts of the Dutch colony with the French colony. The payment was intended to satisfy the colonists who had protested against payment. After a series of violent raids, in 1692 Penn agreed to cede to the settlers in his lands four of the eight parcels that had been ceded by his predecessor.

In 1693 Penn signed the Treaty of Paris. The next year, Penn's father, Sir John Penn, was born in Holland. The Penns came to North America later that year, sailing from England with the first colonists.

completed: “ The roots of all our modern academic fields can be found within the pages of literature. ” Literature in all its forms can be seen as written records , which can also be used to reflect the social and political structures of the different societies . The term “ Literature ” is not an objective and neutral concept , but rather refers to the whole of works in written form , which have no fixed aesthetic qualities or criteria . Literature is therefore more of a subjective experience to which each individual can contribute his own a esthetical qualities according to taste and individual disposition . Literature has also not always been confined to books . Some of the first written documents , that came into existence in the course of evolution , were no doubt epics , stories , songs or poems . But , despite the great many forms , Literature can generally be divided into three categories : prose , poetry and drama Literature contains a full range of artistic forms

original: Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding" plumage, or—in the Humphrey-Parkes terminology—"basic" plumage; breeding plumages or variations of the basic plumage are known under the Humphrey-Parkes system as "alternate" plumages. Moulting is annual in most species, although some may have two moults a year, and large birds of prey may moult only once every few years. Moulting patterns vary across species. In passerines, flight feathers are replaced one at a time with the innermost primary being the first. When the fifth of sixth primary is replaced, the outermost tertiaries begin to drop. After the innermost tertiaries are moulted, the secondaries starting from the innermost begin to drop and this proceeds to the outer feathers (centrifugal moult). The greater primary coverts are moulted in synchrony with the primary that they overlap.

Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding plumage".

The feathers on the head and flanks, the talons and the beak (gizzard) are all considered part of the pre-breeding plumage and so must be removed, and sometimes a part of a bird that has moulted must be preserved to protect itself from predation.

It is thought that after breeding the sexes develop different plumage, because in early development, all other parts of the bird are covered with the same feather cells.

However, not all parts of the plumage are equally important in survival. The beak is thought to be one of the most important parts in pre-breeding plumage because of the importance of a beak to feeding, and to helping a bird keep a balance in balance between itself and the environment.

original: As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as free radicals can form. Most of these are oxidizers (i.e., acceptors of electrons) and some react very strongly. For the continued normal cellular maintenance, growth, and division, these free radicals must be sufficiently neutralized by antioxidant compounds. Recently, some researchers suggested an interesting theory of evolution of dietary antioxidants. Some are produced by the human body with adequate precursors (glutathione, Vitamin C), and those the body cannot produce may only be obtained in the diet via direct sources (Vitamin C in humans, Vitamin A, Vitamin K) or produced by the body from other compounds (Beta-carotene converted to Vitamin A by the body, Vitamin D synthesized from cholesterol by sunlight). Phytochemicals (Section Below) and their subgroup, polyphenols, make up the majority of antioxidants; about 4,000 are known. Different antioxidants are now known to function in a cooperative network. Most of these are created outside of cells due to the action of UV radiation as a direct byproduct of DNA replication. Other free radicals, which are the cause of disease, are formed in cell walls, macromolecules, and in specialized parts of cells called mitochondria. Mitochondria contain the cells' DNA, and therefore have a special role in metabolism (see the page about Energy Production, Energy Supplies and Energy Metabolism for more information).

Most of these are oxidizers ( i.e. , electron-acceptor compounds ) that cause cellular damage by attacking and altering the cell membrane , proteins or DNA . Free radicals can neutralize each other within a cell , but it is possible for reactive species to be released into the environment and , therein , damage neighboring cells . While the body is able to reduce the effects of free radicals ( primarily through antioxidants like Vitamin E , as corbate , alpha lipo ic acid and vitamin C ) , this requires a steady supply of micronutrients . This problem becomes more acute as we age because , as we will later consider , our bodies are less capable of absorbing nutrients ( micronutri ents )

Curzon's decision angered both Hindus and Muslims in Bengal. His successor, Lord Macaulay, appointed an all-Muslim Council to negotiate with British politicians over Bengal's future. Their offer was to give equal rights to Hindus and Muslims within the existing British Indian empire, but for Curzon to get the Indians to accept this would require the British to give up control of India, which was seen as a threat to the interests of both the United Kingdom and Curzon himself.

Curzon was opposed by the most senior British official in Bengal, Prime Minister David Lloyd George (no relation to the famous Victorian archaeologist). original: The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s, for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical things could not be translated into statements about actual and possible sense data. This UN plan specified borders for the new State of Israel with its capital in Tel Aviv, its population in Israel excluding the Arab minority, and the rights and obligations of the displaced Palestinian groups.

The Partition Plan was submitted by an international commission, headed by the United Kingdom and Sweden. The commission, which met as the United Nations Economic and Social Council on 14 and 16 December 1947, met a few months before the UN vote on the Partition Plan.

original: Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. It has a history of use that is at least 10,000 years old, and estimates of its discovery place it at 9000 BC in the Middle East; a copper pendant was found in northern Iraq that dates to 8700 BC. There is evidence that gold and meteoric iron (but not iron smelting) were the only metals used by humans before copper. The history of copper metallurgy is thought to have followed the following sequence: 1) cold working of native copper, 2) annealing, 3) smelting, and 4) the lost wax method. In southeastern Anatolia, all four of these metallurgical techniques appears more or less simultaneously at the beginning of the Neolithic c. 7500 BC. Species are increasingly being moved by humans ( on purpose and by accident ) farther from the original range of the species , a process called introduction . With increasing human transportation , the range of species can quickly expand , making the introduction and expansion of non-indigen ous species ( alien species ) the main reason for biodiversity loss . Introduced species often come into competition with native species in areas where they can thrive in conditions that are less than ideal . They have an advantage if they are better adapted to new habitats , or can tolerate environmental changes much more easily and rapidly . Because the invasive species are so different from the native species , they often out-compete locally adapted species and prevent them from adapting to new habitats . Despite the huge advances made throughout the century, the technology remained somewhat inefficient. The phonautographer was expensive, prone to malfunction and would require manual adjustments due to the poor quality of microphones and speaker combinations.

In 1927, J. P. Morgan and J. W. Carnegie had the idea to combine Edison's invention with other new technologies to create the first commercial computer. To create a sound recording of the same length as a human voice, a two-inch tape was mounted with a microphone to record audio with the voice. Using a reel-to-reel player, players would play a record using an electromagnet, which would rotate the tape along with the needle, resulting in recording sound. At this level of performance, the record could be sent across the radio frequency transmission spectrum by radio receivers, effectively creating a computer.

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and reproduction; it is involved in the regulation and elimination of toxins; it is responsible for the production and destruction of cell structures, including the cell nucleus [9]. original: Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. But the transition from literary writing to the written language was not yet complete; the majority of people in this region still spoke literary Cyrillic for a few years, even if not necessarily on a daily basis. original: The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the island is covered in basaltic volcanoes). The island lies in some of the most extreme weather regimes on Earth. For example, the island experiences average winter temperature of -58.2° Celsius, which is 0.5° Celsius warmer than the global average of -40.9° and -42.1° Celsius respectively.


In terms of surface area it is smaller than that of the continental United States. On average, over the last 25 years around 6,100 residents have emigrated each year from the island.

Geographically, the island of Saint Helena is characterized by thick volcanic tectonic plate boundaries. The volcanic surface is composed mainly of basaltic lava. In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12 hours of footage each night. This was called the "Midnight Special."

In a way, it's the classic recording for its time. Though Gabler uses a more technical approach than many sound men of the time, he still makes interesting use of the microphones and his own vocal stylings to create a story and, most importantly, capture the essence of the events taking place. There is a great deal of tension and mystery built into each recording. Here, he is in a small cottage; a very dangerous place to be at night. One minute he's out front; the next, up inside his own home. There's lots of very tense moments of negotiation, some shouting and much shouting. Most memorable is a shot of a woman screaming; an event that is of great importance to the characters in Gabler's stories.

The label had a reputation for `` jazz `` which proved to be an attractive alternative to the more mainstream Victor and RCA records with `` easy listening `` dance music such as Big Bands . The label later also did some R & B recordings with Little Esther Jackson and Harry James . original: The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841. In 1843 the possibility of war was anticipated by the state government and it began to reinforce the defense lines along the political boundary with Texas. Supplies of weapons were sent to fully equip the military and took steps to improve efficiency at the presidios. Later, the Regimen for the Defenders of the Border were organized by the state which were made up of: light cavalry, four squads of two brigades, and a small force of 14 men and 42 officials at the price of 160,603 pesos per year. During the beginning of the 1840s, private citizens took it upon themselves to stop the commercial caravans of supplies from the United States, but being so far away from the large suppliers in central Mexico the caravan was allowed to continue in March 1844.

The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841. In 1843 the Mexican-American War started. The Mexican Army of Conquest was launched, and the conflict continued sporadically until 1848 when the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo ended it. The conflict had major effects on the entire country as well as within Texas, leading to the establishment of the United States and eventually the Texas and Mexican Wars. It created numerous ethnic and racial conflicts, particularly between Anglo settlers and free soil Mexicans as warring factions formed in the Rio Grande Valley, San Antonio, and other Mexican border towns.

The U.S. and Mexican War

The outbreak of war with Mexico took place in mid-1847, when the United States invaded Mexico. The conflict eventually became known as what is commonly called the Mexican American War (in reference to both countries), the Texas Revolution, or simply the War.
